unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Age vs. Test Score on Standardized Test
question_text:
Suppose all students took a standardized test at a local school.
The students were between ages $8$ and $12\text{ years old}$.
Linear regression was performed on age vs. test score. The computer output is below:

Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: There is insufficient evidence to suggest a linear relationship between age and test scores.

According to this model, we can expect students will increase their score by an average of
0.4349
 points per year
on this test.

According to this model, we can expect students will increase their score by an average of
7.8151
 points per year
.
This model would be appropriate to use to predict scores of college age students.

The
p
-value indicates no relationship between age and score.

solution:
The definition of slope is the change of
y
for one change in
x
. Using this definition in the context of the problem, every year, on average, test scores will increase by
0.4349
.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; with a very low
p
-value (
p
=
0.0003421
), strong evidence exists of a linear relationship between age and test scores.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; this attempts to explain slope in the context of the problem but gives the value for the
y
-intercept, not the slope.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; increases in this model will most likely level off, and it is always unwise to predict values far outside the range of data.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; a low
p
-value means a result such as this one would be very unlikely to happen by chance. Since the
p
-value is so low (
p
=
0.0003421
), there is strong evidence of a linear relationship between age and test score.
